Period ended May 26, 1924. THE unemployment figures given in Part I (A) of this report show a decreasefor this period of 32,154 or 3-1 per cent, of the total number of unemployed personsregistered on the 28th April. The improvement in employment was steadily maintained throughout theperiod to which this report relates, the' reductions in the number of personsunemployed in each of the four weeks being respectively 7,120, 14,522, 5,106 and5,406. To some extent this resulted from seasonal causes, but it will be seen fromPart II of the report that the industries of shipbuilding and engineering contributedtowards the general improvement. T. Increase 1,838Treorchy. Increase 1,230clue to stoppage of collieries. II.-POSITION IN CHIEF INDUSTRIES. Coal Mines. A decline in employment has occurred in this industry, due to the seasonal decrease in home consumption and to a falling off in export trade. In the North-Eastern Collieries the depression has chiefly been felt in Durham and Northumberland, particularly in the coal-exporting centres. Employment in the South Yorkshire collieries, however, has continued to be satisfactory. In the Lancashire area there has been a falling off in orders and consequently less work, but the decrease in trade is only regarded as temporary. In the Midlands, employment has remained normal in North and South Staffordshire, but a slight falling off in demand is now beginning to be felt in other centres. Short-time working has commenced at Chesterfield, where 8,000 men are working four days per week. In the South-Western counties the Bristol pits are fairly busy, but work is slacker in the Somerset coal-fields. The position in the Forest of Dean area is not at all satis- factory, largely due to bad export trade, but also to the decreased home demand. Unemployment and short-time working have resulted. In Wales and Monmouthshire the position has become worse owing to a reduction in demand, which in turn caused a shortage of wagons. Approximately 22,000 men have been involved by the stoppage of collieries in this area, hut in some cases these collieries are now working inter- mittently, or have resumed full-time' working. The problem of securing suitable employment for men in the more advanced age groups, particularly unskilled men, is becoming increasingly difficult. In Scotland there has been a falling off in demand from home and foreign markets. Short-time is being worked at Airdrie and Ayr. At the latter place difficulty is being experienced owing to the lack of wagons. Stone Quarries. Employment generally remains good in this industry. China Clay. There is no change to report in this industry. The Cornish pits are still very busy, but there is still a considerable surplus of labourers. Iron Mines. There is no change of importance to record in this industry. Unemployment continued to be heavy in the Cleveland district and in Cumberland. Tin Mines. A further slight improvement has occurred in Cornwall. IRON AND STEEL PRODUCTION. The position in this industry has not improved, although certain individual centres showed signs of improvement. In the North-Eastern Counties no appreciable change has taken place except at Middlesbrough, where suspensions of men have occurred.. A special feature in this area is the import of 100 tons of pig iron from India for making up into railway chairs and reshipment to India. Foundries in Sheffield are understood to have more work in hand than was the case a year ago, and firms engaged in the manufacture of steel sheets are maintaining their rate of production. Makers of manganese steel points and crossings are actively engaged on increased orders received from Home and Colonial Corporations. Manufacturers of railway material are still busy. In the North-Western Counties, full time is being worked at Workington, and the iron furnaces are in full blast. Employment has also improved in the steel furnaces. At Barrow the Haematite Steel Company anticipate reopening their works during the next few weeks. In the Midlands area unemploy-ment is still heavy and the position is unstable. A firm of ironfounders at Tiptonhas closed down, and 200 men have' been discharged. Trade is very poorat West Bromwich and Cradley Heath, but there has been improvement at BrierleyHill and Stourbridge. In the central Midlands area the position has improvedslightly. In the Welsh area there is a slight falling off in activity, but the positionremains fairly satisfactory. In Scotland the demand continues to be limited, but any improvement is dependent upon activity in the shipbuilding industry. It isreported from Motherwell that exceptionally large quantities of foreign partly- [11728] ' B 2 finished steel have been imported, which is having an adverse effect upon the puddlingsection of the tube works.TIN-PLATE TRADE. Continued activity is still being experienced in Wales and there is no falling offin trade. In the South-Western Counties at Lydney and Bristol, firms are still busy.SHIPBUILDING AND SHIP-REPAIRING. There is a steady though slight improvement to record in this industry, and reports from all districts show that work is now proceeding more regularly. In theNorth-Eastern Counties orders for new vessels have been placed at Middlesbrough,South wick, Stockton, Thornaby and West Hartlepool. In the North-western counties also there has been a definite improvement, particularly at Barrow. Inthe Merseyside area repair work still continues to provide employment for increasing numbers. The position in the London area is still bad, but a slight improvement inthe South-Eastern Counties is apparent, especially at Gravesend and Chatham.Increased activity is also being experienced at Yarmouth and Lowestoft, due topreparation for the fishing season. In the South-Western Counties ship repairershave been busy at Southampton and Woolston finishing up arrears of work following the strike. At Avonmouth the repair yards are somewhat slacker, but at bristol and Cowes a steady improvement has been made. There was little or no improvementin Wales except at Swansea, where increased employment was available. AtScotland several contracts have been finished which have accounted for a few .discharges, but these are neutralised by the fact that new orders are coming in orin contemplation. At Dundee only three out of ten slips are empty, and it isanticipated that these berths will be commissioned in the near future. New orders have been received at Clydebank, Port Glasgow, Dumfries and burnt island. Not-withstanding these indications of improvement, unemployment in this industry onthe Clyde continues to be heavy, and the prospects of revival are not encouraging.ENGINEERING. Motor and Cycle Engineering.-The employment position in this branch of theindustry continues to be good. In the North-Western Counties the general activity has been maintained, except at Trafford Park, where discharges by the Ford motor company have taken place, alleged to be due to the falling off of orders. In the Midlands area trade is still good and the general improvement main-tained, although the outlook is uncertain. There has been a slight setback atCoventry, due to discharges by the Morris Motors, Limited (350 men), and by theTriumph Cycle Company. At Birmingham the motor-cycle trade is good, and orders are still on hand.The motor-car trade also remains good, with the exception of the Calthorpe motor company, who have discharged 500 men, and are in process of voluntary liquidation.Trade is good at Derby/and has improved at Redditch, where overtime is beingworked by the Enfield Cycle Company. At Northfield (Birmingham) the Austin Motor Company, Limited, continue to bebusy on small cars, and workers are being taken back at Tipton by Messrs. Harper,Sons and Bean. The Raleigh Cycle Company at Nottingham are still very busy,and contemplate extending their premises at an early date. In the South-Eastern Counties the position has scarcely changed. Activitycontinued in the manufacture of commercial motor vehicles, but in the case of lightmotor-cars the position is uncertain and discharges have taken place. On the otherhand, a firm at Southall have notified vacancies for fitters, builders, turners andpainters used to light-car work. In the South-Western Counties the tendency is in the direction of improvement.300 workers mainly semi-skilled or unskilled out of the 4,000 hands employed bythe Morris works at Oxford have been discharged, and an auxiliary firm who makeradiators for the Morris cars have placed 200 of their employees on short-time. TheDouglas motor-cycle works at Bristol are still working at high pressure. At Poolework on motor-body building is still busy, and at Swindon motor firms are fully employed. Seasonal activity on repair work is evident. General Engineering, This branch of the industry continues to show improve-ment. In the Sheffield area structural firms are understood to be very busy, and dropped stamped tools are in more demand, whilst files continue to be required in increasing quantities. Twist drill makers are moderately busy, and saw makers are quite fully employed. In the North-Western Counties there' has been a gradual improvement.Textile machinery manufacture appears to be the least affected by this improvement. In the Midlands there is little change to report, and unemployment remainsheavy. Employment in the Electrical Engineering trade at Coventry remains good. In the South-Eastern Counties improvement has been maintained, and work onmarine engines, agricultural implements and printing machinery continues to be good. Work, however, is still slack at East London, Bedford and Ipswich. In the South-Western Counties there has been a continuous steady recovery,especially in ironfounding and agricultural machinery. Agricultural engineeringat Banbiiry shows improvement, and the railway shops at Eastleigh and Swindonare very busy. At Bristol and Newbury work is slack. There has been no improve-ment at Portsmouth, and the Stroud Valley is only moderately busy. In Scotlandan improvement has taken place at Dundee, due to the shipbuilding activity.TEXTILES. Cotton. The position in this industry showed little.change, increased employ-ment at some centres being balanced by decline at others. Employment has been well maintained in the manufacture of high-grade goods, but in the American cottonspinning section, and in the manufacture of cheaper cloths for the Indian and chinese markets, curtailment of production continued. Short-time in the finishingsection of this industry tends to increase. In most branches of the industry there isstill an appreciable amount of under-employment, and in several cases four days aweek are being worked, whilst in other cases operatives are employed on only two orthree looms instead of the normal complement of four looms per weaver. Woollens and Worsteds. The position in this industry is fairly good, but is somewhat uncertain. There has been a sudden depression in the wool-combing sectionat Bradford. Other woollen textile districts in Yorkshire, however, show a slightimprovement. The piece-goods trade continues to improve, especially in the home market. Far Eastern business is on the slack side, but there is a distinct improve-ment in the general position. Steady improvement is reported from Scotland. Hosiery. The position remains good in most districts, but in the underwearsections short-time is still being worked. At Ilkeston, Rugby and Ruddington(Notts) improvement has been maintained, but work is slack at Sutton-in-Ashfieldand Derby. A similar situation obtains in Scotland. Lace. In the Midlands area there is a considerable amount of unemployment,and trade is very depressed at Basford, but there has been a slight improvement inthe curtain section. At Beeston, in the curtain sectionj there has been a temporaryslump, but trade is better in the plain net section. The leavers' section continuesvery slack. Improved trade is reported from Long Eaton and Ilkeston. Improvedemployment is also reported from Barnstaple and Torrington. Silk. The position generally is very satisfactory, and the dyeing departments at Leek are busier. The artificial silk industry at Derby is still busy. Trade continuesgood at Coventry^and Longton. Jute. There is no change to report. At Dundee a shortage of weavers is stillresponsible for the unemployment of other workers in the main, but a further causeis the anticipated fall in the price of jute, causing employers to postpone buyingraw material until the present production is worked off. Carpets. General improvement is maintained in this industry, and there is continued prosperity at Kidderminster. The factories at Stroud, Salisbury andSwindon are still working whole-time.BUILDING AND BRICK AND TILE MANUFACTURE. The position in this industry is very satisfactory, and a high level of activity ismaintained. In the North-Eastern counties work is continued at high pressure, andthere is a proposed extension in housing schemes by colliery companies at Barnsleyand Moxborough. In the North-Western area the work is brisk, but is restrictedsomewhat by the scarcity of skilled workers, all efficient bricklayers, joiners, masonsand plasterers being employed. Seasonal activity is keeping painters and decoratorsfully employed. In the Midlands area employment is good in all sections, and there is increasedemployment amongst painters. In most areas there is a shortage of skilled workmen and an increasing demand for plasterers. In the South-Eastern counties the demand for bricklayers and joiners exceeds the supply, though the demand for plasterers has slackened somewhat. A firm of paper manufacturers at Sittingbourne contemplate building 750 houses to accommodate their workpeople. In the South-Western counties work is steady, and there is a shortage of skilled workers. At Gloucester the Corporation Housing Scheme is in full swing. At Portsmouth the shortage of bricks has now been met, and work is busy. In Wales and Scotland there is increased activity, and the shortage of skilled labour in these areas is also felt. In the brick and tile trade employment is generally good, and the demand for Fletton building bricks at Wellingborough is greater than the output. At Hanley full pressure of work is maintained, and a local firm contemplate enlarging their plant. In the South-Western area trade is brisk at Bridgwater and Bristol. CLOTHING. The general seasonal improvement is maintained, especially in the tailoring and dressmaking trades. In the corset trade some slight improvement has been made at Ipswich, but there is still considerable unemployment. Trade in this industry is good at Kettering and also at Leicester; short-time is being worked at Derby. In thei shirt and collar trade work is better at Taunton. In the glove trade work is in full swing at Barnstaple, Yeovil and Torrington. BOOT AND SHOE. - There has been an improvement in most areas in this industry, except in the Midlands. At Leicester there has been a rush of orders for Whitsuntide1, but a slackening-off after this period is expected. Full-time is maintained at Mansfield, Bromsgrove and Northampton factories, and there is a slight improvement at Kettering, Wellingborough and Rushden. At Derby and Coalville short-time is being worked. Trade is very poor at Raunds,Wollaston and Wolverhampton. In the South-Eastern counties there is little change to report. Trade isgenerally busy, but there is a fair amount of surplus labour. At Norwich the industryis in a satisfactory condition, and 9,000 operatives are employed, which is almostequal to the pre-war figure. In the South-Western counties there has been a rapid improvement, which is,however, considered to be only temporary. The Bristol firms generally are slack. AtKingswood there has been a sudden rush of work to make up depleted stocks after heavy consignments to Ireland, prior to the imposition of an import duty by the FreeState Government.POTTERY. Employment is still below normal, but there is a slight improvement. All areasin the South-Western counties are still busy, and little unemployment prevails. In the Midlands at Hanley increased activity is manifest in the better class ofchina and earthenware. Conditions generally are better at Longton, Burslem andNewcastle-under-Lyme.TRANSPORT. Little improvement has taken place, except of a seasonal nature. In the North-Eastern counties there has been an increase of employment amongmerchant seamen at Blyth, North Shields and Sunderland. At Boston the BostonDeep Sea Fishing and Ice Company, Limited, are leaving the port, and the majorityof fishermen in this area will have to seek work at other ports. In the North-Western counties unemployment is very heavy at the docks; this is largely due to the poor state of the cotton industry. In the South-Eastern counties work at the docks continues to be steady. In the South-Western area work at the docks is rather quiet. There is improvedemployment among seamen, which suggests an early increase of activity at the docks.At Bristol and Avonmouth there has been a slight depression due to the slackening ofthe timber trade. Weymouth is already benefiting by the opening of the channel islands season. In the Welsh area conditions are good, and employment has improvedat Newport, Barry and Swansea, while the position at Cardiff is better. III. OVERSEAS SETTLEMENT. (Colonial Office.) tinder the Empire Settlement Act, 1922, assisted passage schemes for Australia,New Zealand, Canada and Ontario have been agreed with the Dominion authorities concerned. In addition, schemes for the settlement of immigrants on the land havebeen agreed with the Governments of New South Wales, Victoria and Western Australia. A number of organisations, having as their object the provision of facilities for the settlement of immigrants in certain of the Dominions, have alsobeen assisted. An extension of this assistance to other organisations is underconsideration. With regard to the latter, the methods of financial co-operation are so diverse that it is impracticable to give an aggregated figure of ExchequerAssistance. For this reason, the accompanying Summary is only indicative of theextent to which the Exchequer is involved, and must be regarded as supplementary to, and not in substitution of, the detailed information given in the Tablesthemselves. (Estimates, Class VII, Vote 3.) The National Insurance Act of 1911 provided Insurance against unemploymentin certain selected industries. It was followed by the Act of 1916, which increased the numbers of persons insured, and, in 1920, by an Act of general scope which appliedcompulsory Insurance against unemployment to 12,000,000 persons.
